(e) The right to request auxiliary aids to ensure that communications withndividuals with hearing, vision, or speech impairments are as effective asommunications with others. “Auxiliary aids” include such servicesr devices as qualified interpreters, assistive listening headsets, televisionaptioning and decoders, telecommunications devices for deaf personsTDD’s), videotext displays, readers, taped texts, brailed materials, andarge print materials.

Upon reduction, suspension, and/or termination (including case closure) of anyetermination concerning the furnishing or denial of vocational rehabilitationervices.
